H0.text: Using open flames to heat all materials is a safe practice to exercise during laboratory investigations.

H1.text: Keeping your cell phone on the laboratory countertop is a safe practice to exercise during laboratory investigations.

H2.text: Knowing where your instructor/laboratory leader is at all times is a safe practice to exercise during laboratory investigations.

H3.text: Removing your safety glasses when moving from station to station is a safe practice to exercise during laboratory investigations.

A4.text: Laboratories, especially those using solvents in any quantity, have the potential for flash fires, explosions, rapid spread of fire, and high toxicity of products of combustion (heat, smoke, and flame).

A5.text: Rapid heating (or cooling) may cause uneven thermal expansion putting too much mechanical stress on the surface and cause it to fracture.

A6.text: Correct eye protection should be worn in most experiments involving glassware.

A7.text: Heat-resistant gloves are commonly used as PPE.

A8.text: Goggles with high air flow should be used to prevent fogging.

A9.text: Safety glasses are made with break-proof plastic lenses to protect the eye from flying debris or other matter.

A10.text: Safety glasses are worn to protect the eyes in various situations.

A11.text: Flammable solvents (and rags soaked with solvent) placed in enclosed trash cans

A12.text: Kitchen fires from unattended cooking, grease fires/chip pan fires
